title: Abscessus_analysis
text: study comparing mortality transplant patients: infected Mycobacterium abscessus vs infected. , suggests retrospective cohort study: Patients either exposed unexposed (infection), either experience binary outcome (death). resulting 2x2 table includes cell containing 2 patients, used Fisher’s exact test. hadn’t realised given survival time part data. became concerned throwing information away, standard survival analysis, including log rank test due uncertainty PH assumption. seemed sensible . paper reviewed decision statistical analysis flawed! immortal time bias, exposure (infection) covariate time-varying fixed. revision rejected unless landmark analysis implemented. accept criticism, though also defend original analysis using Fisher’s exact test, think biased. never done landmark analysis (thanks survival analysis book, Dom!). understanding landmark analysis, need choose cut-point. cut-point, (1) data cut-discarded, (2) patients’ infection status allowed change. , patient uninfected cut-point must treated uninfected analysis, regardless happens . 9 (nine) patients infected group. mind, think sensible cut-point day X transplant, X equals smallest day number put 9 infected patients infected group. like hear opinion . analysis moment don’t data; death post-transplant survival/censoring time. think need “number days transplant infection” 9 patients learn X. discard patients died day X, use new survival variable, “survival/censoring time day X”. don’t want paper rejected bad stats(!), really appreciate opinion go ahead.

what: Load packages, load anonymised data, clean the data
title: Abscessus_analysis
code: library(librarian) librarian::shelf(survival, survminer,martinlaw/abscessus, ggplot2, quiet=TRUE)  dat <- read.csv("../data/abscessus_data.csv")  # Create more informative variable names: dat$infected <- ifelse(test=dat$abscessuss_yes_1, yes="Infected", no="Not infected") dat$alive <- ifelse(test=dat$alive_yes_1, yes="Alive", no="Not alive") dat$lung.dysfun <- ifelse(test=dat$CLAD_yes_1, yes="Yes", no="No") dat$airway.injury <- ifelse(test=dat$airway_injury_yes_1, yes="Injury", no="No Injury")  names(dat)[names(dat)=="survival_post_tx"] <- "time" dat$status <- -1*(dat$alive_yes_1-1)

title: Abscessus_analysis
text: Begin 2x2 table: Treating survival binary: difference groups using Fisher’s Exact Test:
code: con <- table(dat$infected, dat$alive) con #>                #>                Alive Not alive #>   Infected         7         2 #>   Not infected    43        16 fisher.test(con)  #>  #>  Fisher's Exact Test for Count Data #>  #> data:  con #> p-value = 1 #> alternative hypothesis: true odds ratio is not equal to 1 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>   0.2147327 14.0893634 #> sample estimates: #> odds ratio  #>   1.297558

title: Abscessus_analysis
code: fit <- survfit(Surv(time, status) ~ infected, data = dat) #ggsurvplot(fit, data=dat) saved_theme <- theme_minimal() + theme(axis.text = element_text(size = 10)) logrank.plot <- ggsurvplot(    fit,                     # survfit object with calculated statistics.    data = dat,              # data used to fit survival curves.     risk.table = TRUE,       # show risk table.    pval = TRUE,             # show p-value of log-rank test.    conf.int = FALSE,         # show confidence intervals for                              # point estimates of survival curves.    #xlim = c(0,2000),        # present narrower X axis, but not affect                             # survival estimates.    #break.time.by = 500,     # break X axis in time intervals by 500.    ggtheme = saved_theme, # customize plot and risk table with a theme.  risk.table.y.text.col = T, # colour risk table text annotations.   risk.table.y.text = FALSE, # show bars instead of names in text annotations                             # in legend of risk table  title="Figure 1: Kaplan-Meier survival curves", ) logrank.plot png(filename="../figs/logrank_plot.png", width=8, height=6, units="in", res=300) logrank.plot dev.off() #> agg_png  #>       2

title: Abscessus_analysis
text: log-rank test finds difference survival times two groups, appropriate model assume proportional hazards.
code: fit.diff <- survdiff(formula(fit), data=dat) fit.diff #> Call: #> survdiff(formula = formula(fit), data = dat) #>  #>                        N Observed Expected (O-E)^2/E (O-E)^2/V #> infected=Infected      9        2     2.48    0.0937     0.109 #> infected=Not infected 59       16    15.52    0.0150     0.109 #>  #>  Chisq= 0.1  on 1 degrees of freedom, p= 0.7 # P value: fit.diff$pvalue #> [1] 0.7415316  obs.exp.ratios <- fit.diff$obs/fit.diff$exp # Hazard ratio: obs.exp.ratios[1]/obs.exp.ratios[2] #> [1] 0.7814048  # Confidence interval (not valid for log-rank, according to Bland and Altman) # obs.minus.exp <- fit.diff$obs[1]-fit.diff$exp[1] # V <- fit.diff$var[1,1] # # V <- obs.minus.exp^2 / fit.diff$chisq # equivalent calculation # K <- obs.minus.exp/V # log.lower <- K-1.96*sqrt(V) # log.upper <- K+1.96*sqrt(V) # ci <- exp(c(log.lower, log.upper)) # ci

title: Abscessus_analysis
text: Fitting Cox proportional hazards model also show effect, though plot , assumption proportional hazards appears hold.
code: cox.no.covar <- coxph(Surv(time, status) ~ infected, data = dat) # Test PH assumption: cox.zph(cox.no.covar) #>          chisq df   p #> infected 0.147  1 0.7 #> GLOBAL   0.147  1 0.7 plot(cox.zph(cox.no.covar)) summary(cox.no.covar) #> Call: #> coxph(formula = Surv(time, status) ~ infected, data = dat) #>  #>   n= 68, number of events= 18  #>  #>                        coef exp(coef) se(coef)     z Pr(>|z|) #> infectedNot infected 0.2468    1.2799   0.7502 0.329    0.742 #>  #>                      exp(coef) exp(-coef) lower .95 upper .95 #> infectedNot infected      1.28     0.7813    0.2942     5.569 #>  #> Concordance= 0.514  (se = 0.038 ) #> Likelihood ratio test= 0.12  on 1 df,   p=0.7 #> Wald test            = 0.11  on 1 df,   p=0.7 #> Score (logrank) test = 0.11  on 1 df,   p=0.7 recip.coef <- -summary(cox.no.covar)$coef[1] se <- summary(cox.no.covar)$coef[3] ci <- exp(c(recip.coef-1.96*se, recip.coef+1.96*se)) ci #> [1] 0.179566 3.399374
